Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2013 09:51AM jwilco wrote: I felt the same at my first mamo after surgery.  I had a mamo on the non BC side and then ultrasound on both.  I also had the mamo and had to go back for more images.  I hated the anxiety sitting there waiting caused.  I have a cyst on my non BC side so they always look at that.  Thank the Lord all was fine.  But that anxiety.  I get it before my check ups with the BC surgeon too.  I'm trying to practice mindful meditation while waiting at these type of appts.  Just concentrating on breathing in and out and letting those awful thoughts pass on by like ugly floats in a parade.  It helps.
Posts.Title: First mammogram since surgery and treatment KimbytheSea terrikoala

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2016 04:48PM jwilco wrote: KathyL642 - our stats are very similar. I think the way you feel and the anxiousness is normal. I felt the same way too. It will get better with each appt and annual exam. This October is my 5 year anniversary. I still worry if I think too much about the what ifs, but I try not to let my mind go there. Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Stage 1 and struggling KathyL624 gkbuser

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 11:48PM - edited Nov 6, 2011 12:42AM by jwilco Hi,  I'm in the SF Bay Area and had my diagnosis and surgery at Mills Peninsula.  They have a great BC team, BS, PS, MO, etc.  They all work together.  I didn't qualify for nipple sparing surgery due to a prior breast reduction, however it was mentioned so I believe they do it.  I had skin sparing with latissimus reconstruction.   Not sure if this location is an option for you.  I hope you end up not needing to find out and that your problem isn't BC.
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday - Lot's of Questions QuinnCat blg

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 07:03PM jwilco wrote: Added to my favorites list so when I'm feeling down I can read again and remind myself.  Thank you!
Posts.Title: Things the past year has taught me... SelenaWolf tenaj

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 05:29PM jwilco wrote: Sorry you had to find your way here, but you will find a wealth of information.  I know it's sucks.   Trying to choose between two really rotten choices.   When I first met with the BS team I was shocked when I heard the word mastectomy, but after hearing all of the options as they pertained to my case, I found it was the best decision.  I had skin sparing UMX with immediate reconstruction with the latissimus and implant.  That was the best choice...for me.  Meet with your surgeons, both BS and plastic, and find out all your options.  While my surgery was a little more intense since it involved a muscle flap, it was something I could handle.  There are so many options but I think it really is up to you and your situation. Good luck and try not to be too overwhelmed with all the info.  Sounds like you have some time to make a decision.
Posts.Title: Such heavy decisions... katiebug msphil

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2013 03:29PM jwilco wrote: I have pondered the very same thing.  Reliving my life and wondering what I did that could have caused this.  But you can't do that.  I've decided to move forward and try to do things that will be healthy and also make me feel better both mentally and physically.  Reduce stress is a big one for me.  I thought about going vegan but heck, even vegans can get cancer.  So while what you eat can keep you healthier and avoid many diseases, it unfortunately isn't a magic shield.
Posts.Title: What changes have you made after dx? Speedy4 msphil

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 06:47AM jwilco wrote: drain drain go away....It's been three weeks and I still have my drain in my back.  I've been very anxious to just get it taken out already.  But after reading all your posts I'm thinking maybe I should be patient and wait it out.  I've had drains in the past and had the fluid out via needle.  Not fun.   rkt - I hope they are able to get your situation stable.  I feel for you.
Posts.Title: Healing of Seroma - Need Help! rkt Pattyanne

Posts.Content: jwilco wrote: I met with the oncologyst yesterday.  I had thought it would be the type of meeting where he said either yes I recommend chemo or no, just the Tamoxifen.  Well it wasn't.  He had a lot of percentages about the recurrence based on without any treatment, with Tamoxifen only and then with chemo.  The difference with the chemo was only 3%.  I'm so confused.  I have IDC, >1cm, stage 1, ER/PR+, Her2-, no nodes involved.  Still waiting on the Oncotype.  I'm 47.  I had a UMX with reconstruction already. I'm scared and feel like I can't make a decision. Dx 8/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: help with advice about chemo decision jwilco jwilco

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2011 02:34PM jwilco wrote: Regarding  a second opinion.  There are other oncologysts in the medical group.  Is it ok to get the opinion from one of them or do I need go outside that group?
Posts.Title: help with advice about chemo decision jwilco jwilco

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 01:58AM - edited Nov 5, 2011 02:01AM by jwilco Thank you for your opintions.  Keep em commin'.   My BS said she didn't think I would need chemo so that made me think I wouldn't have to do it. But then the onco appt was very vague.  He didn't say yes do chemo, but then he didn't say no you are fine not doing it.  I'm really concerned about the side effects vs the gain in percentage.  I've had gastric bypass so I'm not sure what difference that makes in any of this too.  My liver already works overtime for some things.  I'm hoping my onco score will be able to help me make my final decision.
Posts.Title: help with advice about chemo decision jwilco jwilco

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2013 11:23AM - edited Mar 24, 2013 11:23AM by jwilco I'm lucky too.  Had surgery (lat UMX) and am on tamoxifen.  So I'm very lucky.  My dr appts are down to only once or twice a year.  Mamo/ultrasound once a year.  I've had some scares, fat necrosis lump, found out I have a thyroid growth but thankfully it is not cancerous.  Still that biopsy took me right back to the BC one. My problem is that sometimes I'm scared to do a self exam.  Afraid I might feel something.  I know it's important because that is how I found my BC.  By doing my own exam.  It never showed on the mamo.  Still, sometimes I'm terrified to feel my good breast.  Anyone else feeling like this?
Posts.Title: <1 cm - Stage 1a - Team 4My3kids rosecal954

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 10:07PM jwilco wrote: It's been a couple of years for me and I think like the others have said, time works wonders.  I too felt like you did at a support group.  I try to eat and live healthier, take my Tamoxifen every day.  Luckily the side effects are minimal for me.  I have found that yoga with meditation helps me to focus and quiet the thoughts when they come.  That also helps for stress of worrying.  I too feel very anxious before my appts, but am so thankful they have all gone well. Give yourself some time.  Read positive posts.  Take time to stop worrying and live life.
Posts.Title: How's your mental health/stress level, stage 1 ladies? CeciliaVera farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2011 12:46PM - edited Nov 12, 2011 02:04PM by jwilco B123 - I feel like I'm just like you with the worrying.  I am still trying to make my final decision on chemo.  I had UMX on 10/11/11, through all my conversations with my BS when I mentioned not knowing about chemo she always said she didn't think I would have to do it.  All the members of the "team" meet together about the patients.  So she had already had conversations/meetings with my oncologyst.  I was at that time still waiting on the HER2 status.  I have IDC >1cm, ER/PR+, 0/1 node.  The HER2 came back as negative.  So when I finally met with the oncologyst after my surgery he didn't come out and say Yes you need chemo, nor did he come out and say NO you don't need chemo.  He just stated a bunch of percentages and that chemo decreased my recurrance by 3%.  My real benefit was the Tamoxifen, which I already knew I would need to take.  I decided to get the Onco test done to help with my decision but after going back and reading through all my paperwork they gave me with all the recommendations from the beginning, no where in there is the section for chemo marked.  It was lumpectomy/radiation/homone or it was mastectomy/hormone.   I'm really really feeling stressed with this decision.  I meet again with the oncologyst on Tuesday.  Deep inside I don't want to do the chemo.  I'm worried that it will be too hard on me and not really guarantee anything.
Posts.Title: Mixed recommendations B123 Joan811

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 04:21PM jwilco wrote: Joan811 - Hi.  Thanks for asking.  I ended up waiting to see how my next appt went with the original MO before deciding on seeing someone else.  I had decided that if my Oncotype score was high or if he was still sort of wish-washy about treatment options then I would gather more opinions.  So when I went last week I felt a lot better with the discussion I had with the original MO.  He did have my Oncotype results.  I was, if I remember correctly, an 11 or 12.  I need to ask for a copy since I didn't at the time.  He sounded very ok with my decision for no chemo.  He said that it would only reduce my risk by a very small percentage, 1%.  So I started Tamoxifen the next day.  So far so good.   I did call the coordinating nurse that's been involved with all my doctors and spoke to her about second opinions or switching MO doctors.  She said that I could and her suggestion was to make it like a second opinion and then if I ended up liking one over the other then I could usually just switch.   I have my next appt with this MO in a few months.  If I begin to feel uncomfortable or even uneasy with how things are going then I'll see about switching. But there was such a difference between the first appt and the last that I'm wondering if part of it was just me freaking out a little bit too.
Posts.Title: Mixed recommendations B123 Joan811

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2011 12:30AM jwilco wrote: Joan - Thank you for some insight.  I have my MO appt on Tuesday and well, I'm pretty sure what my decision will be and now I'm hoping I don't have a high Onco number to screw it all up.  It's been very hard.  I've been driving myself nuts with worry and speculation and research and then more worry.
Posts.Title: Mixed recommendations B123 Joan811

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 10:50PM jwilco wrote: I received a call from the dr at the breast center that did the biopsy.  She told me what I had and also told me "you are going to be ok".  She then gave me the dr name and phone number to call and make an appt.  She also gave her number if I had questions.  It was very overwhelming and surreal.  But looking back on the whole experience starting with me finding the lump, I actually think the anticipation and worry about what it was was worse than moving forward and dealing with each appointment, UMX/recon surgery, etc.  At least I felt I was doing something rather than the constant worry prior to the biopsy results.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 02:23PM jwilco wrote: I too miss my breast, or should I say I miss my OLD breast and NIPPLE.  I had a UMX with immediate recon so I'm very greatful it was one time.  Skin sparring but not nipple sparring.  That space where the nipple was, that circle of skin from my back, well, it's just weird.  My husband has a hard time even looking at pictures without the nipples.  But he has been VERY supportive and I know would deal with what ever came my way.  He is looking forward to the nipple reconstruction in March.  Right now I leave a cami or light bra on and no showering together.  It is hard to deal with for me too.  I had a really hard time in the shower, getting dressed, looking in the mirror.  Feel like I have this big foreign object on my chest where my left breast should be.  My implant made me slightly larger so I will also have the other adjusted too.  This all sucks but I do find it amazing that there are so many options for us now.
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 09:51PM jwilco wrote: I'm in the same place.  Diagnosed last Aug, surgery (UMX) in Oct.  My mammo/US is scheduled for Aug 10.  I will say that after my UMX I had a terrible panic scare...I felt a hard lump on my reconstructed side.  My wonderful BS could see the fear in my eyes and immediately phoned the breast center and got me a mamo/US that same day.  I was fine.  The happened this last Feb.  It was fat necrosis from the reconstruction.  I had skin sparring UMS with LatD/implants on the left side.  The radiology dr did both sides with the US and told me that this will be my new normal.  A mamo on the non-BC side and ultrasound on both.  I'm still nervous about my next set of tests in Aug.  I don't think that will ever go away.  But we are very lucky to be online chatting about it.  I'm extremely thankful.
Posts.Title: First mammogram on Friday after diagnosis/treatment Angel123 Girl53

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 11:33PM jwilco wrote: LaDonna - Yes I did!  It was a lot of worry on my part.  You know, you put on the robe, get the mamo part done and then wait to see if they want more pics.  So you sit in the robe waiting room and wait.  I did have to go back in for more mamo pics, and tried not to go there in my mind,  but when I had the ultrasound the dr said it was a benign cyst.  So the right breast has past it's test today!
Posts.Title: First mammogram on Friday after diagnosis/treatment Angel123 Girl53

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2012 11:04AM jwilco wrote: Going to my mamo/us appt this morning.   My husband tells me that worrying about it won't change the outcome.  He is right.  So I am trying not to think about how the last one went.

Let's hope my visualization works.
